ags:resource.dc:title: Apical dominance and height increment of silver fir (Abies alba Mill.) and Norway spruce (Picea abies (L.) Karst.) in lower layer of selection forest

dc:title.dcterms:alternative: Apikálna dominancia a výškový prírastok jedle bielej (Abies alba Mill.) a smreka obyčajného (Picea abies (L.) Karst.) v dolnej vrstve výberkových lesov

dc:creator.ags:creatorCorporate: Technical University in Zvolen, T.G. Masaryka 24, 960 53 Zvolen, Slovak Republic, email: xjadud@tuzvo.sk

dc:description.dcterms:abstract: The aim of this paper was quantifying differences in the height growth (by relative height growth) and in variability of crown morphology (by apical dominance ratio) between silver fir and Norway spruce growing in the lower layer of a selection forest with dominant protective functions. Results of this study showed statistical differences in height increment between the tree species. Growth increment of natural regeneration of Norway spruce in height category (h ≥ 130 cm, DBH1.3 ≤ 5 cm) was higher than growth increment of silver fir in the same height category. The value of RHG reached 0.3 for Norway spruce and 0.007 for silver fir. We found significantly differences in crown morphology using apical dominance ratio (ADR). This value is often used as an index to estimate the “vigor” of the mapped saplings. Silver fir often creates shade type of crown with ADR value under 0.5. Norway spruce crowns show light type of crown. The influence of tree height on height increment as well as ADR values was not statistically significant.
